event: Earliest evidence of human habitation in coastal Ecuador
Valdivia culture develops one of the oldest known pottery traditions in the Americas
Inca Empire expands into Ecuador under Túpac Inca Yupanqui
First Spanish contact during Pizarro’s expedition
Inca civil war ends; Spanish capture Atahualpa in Cajamarca
Spanish conquistadors capture Quito and found the city
Quito becomes an audiencia under the Viceroyalty of Peru
Quito economy thrives on textile production (obrajes) and agriculture
First call for independence in Quito, briefly establishes autonomous junta
Battle of Pichincha secures independence from Spain
Ecuador joins Gran Colombia under Simón Bolívar
Ecuador secedes from Gran Colombia and becomes independent republic
Marcist Revolution ends dictatorship of Juan José Flores
Gabriel García Moreno unifies the country and strengthens Catholic Church influence
Liberal Revolution led by Eloy Alfaro begins; reduces Church power and modernizes country
Military-led 'Julian Revolution' overthrows corrupt banking elite
War with Peru results in territorial losses for Ecuador
Oil exports begin under military government of Guillermo Rodríguez Lara
Return to democracy with election of Jaime Roldós Aguilera
Roldós dies in plane crash; succeeded by Vice President Osvaldo Hurtado
Brief border war with Peru over Cenepa Valley
Peace treaty with Peru finally resolves border conflict
Economic crisis leads to dollarization under President Jamil Mahuad
Rafael Correa elected president; begins 'Citizen's Revolution' and rewrites constitution
New progressive constitution enacted
Lenín Moreno elected president; breaks from Correa’s political line
Guillermo Lasso elected as Ecuador’s first center-right president in two decades
Daniel Noboa elected as Ecuador’s youngest president amid rising insecurity
